importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Sean 'Diddy' Combs was arrested in September 2024, marking the beginning of a high-profile legal case that drew global attention.
The article was published on October 21, 2025, confirming the latest developments in the appeal process following his conviction and sentencing.
The trial concluded in summer 2024, with the sentencing occurring in September 2024, signaling the end of a lengthy legal process.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 2024 to September 2024 saw the arrest, trial, and sentencing of Sean 'Diddy' Combs, forming the core timeline of the legal case.

keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs was convicted on two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution but acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering.
Combs received a 50-month prison sentence, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation, with Judge Arun Subramanian citing the need for accountability in cases of abuse of women.
Combs had requested a 14-month sentence, but prosecutors sought over 11 years, reflecting a significant disparity in sentencing expectations.
His legal team has announced plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, indicating ongoing legal challenges and potential overturning of key verdicts.
The case involved allegations that Combs used his influence in the music industry to orchestrate a sex trafficking operation, including forcing girlfriends into 'freak-offs' with male escorts.
Two women testified: Cassandra Ventura claimed physical abuse and forced hotel nights; Jane, a pseudonym, said she felt pressured to participate despite being unwell.
The trial attracted international media attention due to Combs' celebrity status and the serious nature of the allegations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a prominent music industry figure, has been convicted on two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation. Despite being acquitted on more serious charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, the conviction stemmed from allegations that he exploited his influence to coerce girlfriends into participating in so-called 'freak-offs' with male escorts. Key testimonies from women including Cassandra Ventura and Jane, who alleged abuse and coercion, fueled the prosecution. Combs expressed remorse and asked for mercy during sentencing, but prosecutors sought over 11 years in prison, while he requested only 14 months. His legal team has now announced plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, reflecting ongoing legal and public scrutiny.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
